sub_title: Inspector (Analytical Chemist) at Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW)
summary:
I am a Chemical Weapons Inspector (Analytical Chemist) within the Technical Secretariat of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons based in The Hague working towards a world free of chemical weapons by verifying compliance of the Chemical Weapons Convention.

Originally from Vancouver, Canada, I have degrees in Analytical Chemistry from Carleton University and The University of British Columbia. Formerly, I was with the R&D arm of Canadian National Defence at DRDC (Defence Research and Development Canada) at the Suffield Research Centre in the Chemical Biological Assessment & Protection section. I am a former Governor of Medicine Hat College that provided governance oversight and strategic vision to the 3,000 student (2100 FTE), 440 employee comprehensive community institution and its $60 million annual budget.

At Carleton, I studied chemistry focusing on analytical chemistry. Under the co-supervision of Dr. RT Patterson & Dr. Bob Burk, my undergraduate thesis used analytical chemistry to explore geochemical markers to identify land use changes preserved in lake sediments. Throughout my undergrad, I was an integral part of Dr. Tim Pattersons Carleton Climate and Environmental Research Group by planning & taking part in field work and preparing & analyzing samples & data.

For my M. Sc. in chemistry, I was part of the Okanagan Regional Chemical Analysis Centre at UBC Okanagan that did a wide variety of chemical analysis using various analytical techniques and instrumentation. I developed novel ionization sources for mass spectrometers and hardware development for chemical analysis. We looked at mechanisms of Photon Induced Chemical Ionization (PICI) in Atmospheric Pressure Photo Ionization systems and Stationary Sample Introduction (SSI) methods. 

At UBC Vancouver, I was working towards a Ph. D. in Experimental Medicine with Dr. Juergen Kast at the UBC Biomedical Research Centre. We were looking at developing new mass spectrometers to better characterize and understand biochemical process of blood. I helped develop hardware to fragment proteins and peptides using photo-generated electrons to induce ECD/ ETD like dissociation to identify post-translational modifications. I also researched new methods to study protein-protein interactions in our studies of causes of cardiovascular diseases.

profile_positions.company: Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW)
profile_positions.description: While working at the OPCW Lab in Rijswijk, I learned many of the key OPCW systems and procedures: ODMS, AMDIS, OCAD, mission preparation, sampling and instrument maintenance/ troubleshooting/ use. With my chemistry and logistics background, I assisted in the preparation of instruments for missions by inventorying and packing. My extensive IT background was useful, when after gaining in depth knowledge of the current version of ODMS, I evaluated beta versions of future versions of ODMS and worked with the software developer to identify and fix bugs. It was a self driven initiative that has led to new, more time efficient solid state hard drives that will soon be deployed in mission laptops. After hearing feedback from an AC inspector about the long time it can take to wipe a mission laptop on some missions I proposed, evaluated and presented results of the new solid state hard drives that are dramatically more time efficient. My extensive mass spectrometry and method development experience was useful when I developed GC-MS/MS methods looking at CW metabolites in biomedical samples that aided in the recent biomedical proficiency testing. I updated, developed and delivered several presentations on behalf of the Lab. In a branding effort, I designed various Lab branded gear (shirts, lab coats, medallions, pens etc). I was eager to assist the Verification Division in various outreach activities including a successful OPCW Open House and science outreach to a local school. My outreach garnered strong praise up to the Director of Verification. Throughout my time at the OPCW, I demonstrated the core values of the OPCW of Integrity, Professionalism and supported Equality. Intern/ contract position.
profile_positions.title: Analytical Chemist

profile_positions.description: As the IT manager for a research centre of 100 people, I had several responsibilities from front line trouble shooting and software installation to back end network management. Alone, I maintained and repaired over 100 research, personal and administrative computers. I was responsible for forecasting and acquisition of hardware & software and advised on enterprise level deployments. Managing IT in a research centre required supporting legacy hardware and software that run various older instruments with new cutting edge research grade computing systems. I modernized many of the administrative and research systems including designing and implementing a mass migration of from a legacy email to a newer standards compliant system with minimal disruption for users.
profile_positions.title: IT Manager

profile_positions.description: My PhD research involved developing new mass spectrometric methods to examine peptides and proteins from biomedical samples. While investigating biochemical properties of blood, I researched the fundamentals of tandem mass spectrometry focused on advancing a new dissociation technique that allowed for characterization of labile (delicate) modifications to peptides in blood samples. I was the principle operator of a QToF instrument and conducted maintenance and repairs (minor and major) to ensure maximum uptime. My research added the capability to detect, not seen before, modifications in blood samples that were relevant for cardiovascular diseases. Conducting research on the proteomic make up of blood gave me significant experience with handling of biomedical material, sample cleanup, extraction, concentration and analysis.
profile_positions.title: Grad Student

profile_positions.description: Managed one of the top rugby clubs in North America.
profile_positions.title: V.P.

profile_positions.description:
I was recognized as one of Apple’s top reps across Canada and even North America by Apple’s senior management team. I had a range of duties that I excelled at and was given increasingly important roles and was selected as a regional manager in charge of hiring, training and management of dozens of sales reps across Canada. Eventually, I was tasked to manage the national program that oversaw 50 employees across Canada.
I demonstrated a keen ability to define goals, formulate strategies, deploy resources and achieve all benchmarks from management. I formulated short and medium term planning to meet the goals of senior management with budgeting responsibilities. My strategic planning and execution was repeatably praised by the most senior levels of Apple Canada Executive team and was noted by executives at Apple world corporate headquarters.
The recognition I received as an outstanding employee by one of the World’s top companies speaks to my professionalism and ability to get things done.
* Note one year educational leave from 2007-2008
profile_positions.title: Apple Campus Representative

profile_positions.description: Empowering a great group of Apple Campus Reps across Canada
profile_positions.title: Campus Rep, Regional Manager

profile_positions.description: My research was focused on hardware and method development for chemical analysis. I gained expert experience with designing and building innovative hardware attachments to expand the capabilities of our instruments. This combined a deep understanding of theoretical knowledge with applied skill to solve analytical problems. I designed and built an inexpensive sampling method for rapid and sensitive analysis of compounds by photo ionization mass spectrometry. The second part of my research was to design and built a simple photo ionization source capable of operating at ambient pressure without specialized gases making it perfect for field sampling. Additionally, as part of the Okanagan Regional Chemical Analysis Centre I used a number of instruments for analysis (both for research/ teaching and fee for service): FTIR, ASE, XRF, ICP OES, Isotope MS, NMR, LC, GC.
profile_positions.title: Grad student
